title: 105_hr4263
content:
The Act is titled the "Four Corners Interpretive Center Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The Four Corners Monument is significant as the only location in the US where 4 state boundaries meet: Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah. Boundary lines were drawn between 1868 and 1875, with a monument erected in 1899. A postal stamp was issued in 1999 to mark the centennial. The area holds historical, cultural, and prehistoric value. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park lacks permanent facilities but attracts visitors annually. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park, located within the Navajo Nation or Ute Mountain Ute Tribe reservations, attracts around 250,000 visitors annually. The Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe have a Memorandum of Understanding for park development. The Four Corners Heritage Council was established in 1992 with state funding for planning and construction of an interpretive center. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park is set for development, with studies showing benefits for the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. Preliminary cost estimates have been completed for an interpretive center and surrounding infrastructure. This center would offer educational opportunities for all Americans, with potential federal assistance and expertise available. Federal financial assistance and technical expertise are needed for the construction of an interpretive center at the Four Corners Monument. The purposes of this Act include recognizing the area's importance, assisting the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in establishing the center, showcasing collaborative resource stewardship, and promoting knowledge of the region's life, art, and culture. The Act aims to promote knowledge of the culturally diverse groups in the Four Corners region, including their life, art, culture, politics, and history. The Act aims to promote knowledge of culturally diverse groups in the Four Corners region, including their life, art, culture, politics, and history. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms related to the Four Corners region, including the Center, Four Corners Heritage Council, Secretary, Recipient, and Four Corners monument. The Four Corners Monument is where the boundaries of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah meet. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park includes lands within its legally defined boundary. The Four Corners Monument Interpretive Center is located at the Four Corners Monument where Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah meet. The Secretary is authorized to establish the Four Corners Interpretive Center within the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. The land for the center will be designated by the Navajo Nation or the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in consultation with the Four Corners Heritage Council and in accordance with relevant agreements. The Four Corners Interpretive Center, to be established within the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park, requires the consent of the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. The center will feature exhibits on the region's heritage, public education programs, preservation efforts, information on cultural and natural resources, and visitor amenities. The construction grant for the Four Corners Interpretive Center within the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park requires consent from the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. The Secretary can award a Federal grant for up to 50% of the construction cost of the Center, with the recipient providing assurances on non-Federal funding sources. States must contribute at least $2,000,000 in non-Federal funds, with equal contributions from each state involved in the grant. States can use private funds to meet the requirements. States can use private funds to meet grant requirements. The State of Arizona may apply $45,000 for planning and $250,000 for construction towards the Arizona share. Recipients must submit a proposal meeting all applicable laws and requirements under a Memorandum of Understanding. The recipient must enter into a Memorandum of Understanding with the Secretary, outlining a timetable for construction completion, competitive awarding of contracts, compliance with building codes, operations and maintenance plans, educational programming, and exhibit design. The recipient must enter into a Memorandum of Understanding with the Secretary for construction completion, contracts, building codes, operations, maintenance, programming, and exhibit design. The agreement with the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe includes site selection and public access. A financing plan outlines long-term management, funding sources, and operating costs covered by fees. The Center must develop a strategy for financial self-sufficiency within 5 years, including defining vendor standards and business activities at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. The Secretary can award a grant under this act, and the Four Corners Heritage Council may provide recommendations on grant proposals for facilities at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate funds for the maintenance and operation of the center, program development, or staffing. Any unexpended funds can be carried over for use until fiscal year 2001. The Secretary may reserve funds until a proposal meeting the requirements is submitted by September 30, 2000. SEC. 8. DONATIONS.

The Secretary can accept donations of funds, property, or services for the Center from private or public entities.

SEC. 9. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION.

This Act does not affect any rights or claims of the Navajo Nation or the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe based on existing laws.
